content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays three separate tissue sections. The two sections on the left and in the center appear to be lymph nodes, characterized by their ovoid shape and dense, basophilic (purple) lymphoid cell population. The section on the right is larger, more irregular, and appears to be the primary tumor, showing complex, somewhat fragmented architecture suggestive of an adenocarcinoma.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

This is the largest lymph node on the slide, located on the far left. When searching for metastasis, I would systematically examine each lymph node. I am zooming into the main body (parenchyma) of this first lymph node to begin the assessment. The goal is to evaluate the overall cellular architecture and to look for any infiltration by non-lymphoid, atypical cells that would be indicative of metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The largest lymph node on the far left is a logical starting point. The specific area highlighted by the green box is in the lower part of the node, potentially near the medullary or cortical sinuses. At low power, this area might have appeared more eosinophilic (pinker) or shown a subtle architectural disruption compared to the surrounding uniform lymphoid tissue, raising suspicion for infiltration by non-lymphoid, metastatic cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task for this case is to stage the cancer, which requires a thorough examination of all lymph nodes for metastasis. The green box is targeting one of the smaller lymph nodes in the central tissue block. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic review of all lymph nodes on the slide. The purpose is to assess the node's architecture at higher magnification, specifically to examine the subcapsular sinus and the lymphoid parenchyma for any clusters of atypical epithelial cells that would indicate metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. When assessing a colorectal cancer case for staging, a critical task is to meticulously search the pericolic fat for all lymph nodes and any suspicious cellular clusters. The area highlighted by the green box is a small, basophilic aggregate that could represent several possibilities: a very small lymph node, a benign lymphoid aggregate, or a tumor deposit (satellite nodule). It is essential to examine such foci at high power to differentiate between these possibilities, as identifying a tumor deposit would upstage the cancer (N-stage). This is part of the routine screening process of the pericolic fat. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a dense, monotonous population of small lymphocytes with dark, round nuclei and scant cytoplasm. There are some small blood vessels traversing the tissue. I do not see any nests of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or significant cytologic atypia. My impression of this specific area is that it represents benign lymphoid tissue, likely part of the lymph node cortex or paracortex. There is no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in this field of view.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals the parenchyma of the lymph node. It is composed predominantly of a dense population of small, dark lymphocytes. However, interspersed within this lymphoid tissue are distinct, irregular nests and clusters of larger, atypical epithelial cells. These cells have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm and larger, pleomorphic nuclei, which stand out against the background lymphocytes. This finding is diagnostic of metastatic adenocarcinoma infiltrating the lymph node. Therefore, this is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the periphery of a lymph node. The top and left portions of the image show dense lymphoid tissue, composed of a population of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. There are some scattered tingible body macrophages, suggesting reactive changes, but no obvious tumor cells. The lymph node is enclosed by a thin, pink, fibrous capsule. This capsule is directly adjacent to mature adipose tissue (perinodal fat) on the right and bottom. My impression of this specific area is that it is negative for metastasis. I do not see any malignant cells infiltrating the capsule or within the subcapsular sinus. The lymph node appears benign/reactive in this field of view.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a well-circumscribed, lobulated aggregate of cells. The cells are uniformly small, with round, dark-staining (hyperchromatic) nuclei and minimal cytoplasm. These features are characteristic of mature lymphocytes. I do not see any atypical cells, glandular structures, necrosis, or significant mitotic activity to suggest malignancy. My impression is that this is a benign lymphoid aggregate within the soft tissue, not a metastatic deposit. This finding is negative for cancer.
